awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Collaborative Research: Optoelectronic Tools for Closed-Loop Neuron Ensemble Recording and Control during Complex Behaviors
awd_abstract_narration:
Brain science will benefit from the capabilities in tracing complex animal behaviors down to ensembles of individual neurons, and moreover establishing a real-time closed-loop brain-interface, ideally with deep brain access in a free-moving animal. This research project aims to address the focus areas in this National Science Foundation program by merging novel neurotechnology, evaluation of neural circuits during performance of complex cognitive behaviors, and large-scale neuron ensemble analysis and closed-loop behavioral control. The outcome of this research will result in new technologies and computational tools that can be used across the field of neuroscience and behavior, strengthening research efforts of multiple research groups. The educational objectives of this proposal are aimed at training and inspiring young engineers and scientists who are equipped with the multidisciplinary background required to help define the future trajectory of brain interfaces and data sciences. The broader impacts of this project include: 1) advancing transformative device technologies for next-generation neurotechnology and providing new and more powerful tools for neuroscience studies, 2) educating underrepresented undergraduate and graduate researchers to contribute to the nation's workforce needs in biotechnology, 3) contributing to the K-12 science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education through weekend seminars and mentoring student-teacher pairs from local middle/high schools; and 4) promoting neuroscience and neurotechnology among local senior citizens and support groups for neurological diseases.  

The research objective of this proposal is to combine high precision optoelectronic neural probes with real-time neural decoding to feedback optogenetic control over animal behavior. Such closed-loop neural interface will establish a generalizable technology platform to study complex animal behaviors using optogenetic tools and real-time learning. The proposed work will open ample research opportunities and form connections among hardware engineering, cognitive neuroscience, and data science. The intellectual merit of the proposed work will be evidenced by three major contributions: 1) demonstration of high-precision optogenetic brain interface that combines multiplexed recording from and bi-directional control over neuron ensembles, 2) demonstration of closed-loop brain interface that employs real-time neural decoding and adaptive learning to control animal behavior, and 3) characterization of complex decision-making using high-precision, multiplexed data linking multiple brain areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Supported by this NSF NCS program, Xu lab has been working to build high resolution closed-loop neural interfaces (i.e. record and control) in the form of optoelectronic probe arrays that can ultimately address the activity of single neurons. The resulting device aims to make the full impact of neural recording, optical neuromodulation, and calcium imaging to trace complex behaviors down to ensembles of individual neurons, ideally with access to deep brain areas.

To date, Xu lab has prototyped three neural probing technologies/devices (in collaboration with Moorman's lab):

1) Close-packed LED arrays for high-precision optogenetics. At the in vitro setting, we achieved optogenetic control of intracellular calcium dynamics of individual cells using high-density micro-LED arrays (16-micon pitches) that feature bright, localized, and fast light output. Individual LEDs can reliably trigger calcium transients, while the entire array can optically control individual cells that are sub-10 µm apart in dense populations. At the in vivo setting, we established a dual-colored micro-LED array monolithically integrated with a low-artifact, low-impedance MEA, all of which are monolithically onto a silicon-based shank structure. The resulting device are able to excite and inhibit the electrical activity of the same group of neurons, namely bidirectional optical control over brain dynamics. We further observed that such optical modulation is specific to which cortex layers we apply such LED-based optical illumination. Such layer-specific studies, in which our scalable probes are well suited, will add to high-resolution dissection of the brain circuitry, shed light on neurological disease models, and promise to trace behaviors down to cellular precision.

2) Wavelength-selective photodiode (PD) arrays for on-chip calcium imaging. We established a spectrally filtered silicon PD array to real-time trace calcium dynamics inside either neurons or C2C12 cells. This array showed high selectivity, high linearity, and low detection limit, therefore well suited to capture intracellular dynamics reported by fluorescent reporters. Moving forward, we are patterning these PDs on the neural probe for multiplexed recording of the neural activity.

3) Surface-modified MEA for high-resolution and low-artifact neurointerfacing. We demonstrated two PEDOT:PSS-coated MEAs, based on graphene and gold, respectively, for high-resolution neurostimulation and neural recording. The PEDOT:PSS layer reduced the electrode impedance down to sub-100 kW in a 28 µm-pitched MEA. The resulting MEA was able to stimulate neural spikes with single electrodes and record optogenetically evoked extracellular signals with low light-induced artifact. We later monolithically integrated these MEAs with LEDs for closed-loop neurointerfacing (see above). 

In the Moorman lab, funds from this award were used to support the following projects.  First, we investigated the contributions of the frontal cortex to decision-making in rats using multi-electrode neuronal recording.  In this study, we created an open-source automated figure-eight maze to permit investigation of different aspects of reward-related decision-making behavior.  We then recorded the activity of dorsomedial frontal cortex neurons during a working-memory based decision-making task to better understand the role of this brain region in cognitive function.  Data from this study are currently under analysis, in collaboration with another PI on this proposal (Meyers).   As part of this project, we also developed new algorithms for removing noise from neurophysiological signals, in order to optimize the data that we collected.  Both aspects of this project are in preparation for publication.  Second, we developed new open-source touchscreen systems for high-throughput cognitive testing in mice and rats.  These systems use Raspberry Pi processors and touchscreens to make powerful, affordable behavioral testing systems that can be used in a variety of environments, including home cages.  We have performed multiple iterations of development on these tools and will continue to refine their development for deployment in the coming months.  Third, funds were used to develop head-fixed behavioral testing systems in awake mice in order to perform cognitive and behavioral testing during the use of high-density recording systems such as Neuropixels or multiphoton recording.  These systems are currently in use in our lab for recording large-scale neuronal activity during behavior.  Fourth and finally, we collaborated with PI Xu to test the opto-electrodes developed in his lab in vivo.  Members of our group used viral vectors to deliver the optogenetic construct BiPOLES into mouse brains.  This construct allows neurons to be activated by red light and inhibited by blue light, optimal for testing the 2-color LED probes developed by PI Xu.  Our group also assisted in optogenetic stimulation and recording the activity neurons in vivo using the Xu lab probes.  The results of this study have been accepted for publication.  Altogether, these funds supported significant progress on the overarching goals of the proposal – to study ensembles of frontal cortex neurons during cognitive tasks, and to develop new tools and analysis techniques for investigating neural signaling during complex cognition and behavior.
